Let’s start with the truth—networks are everything. I didn’t build mine overnight. Over a decade on Wall Street, I learned who to trust, who to watch, and who to keep at arm’s length. Now that the system has failed me—whether by ethics I no longer share or opportunities that slipped through—I rely on those relationships more than ever.

I stay ahead by understanding the flow of information. The real money doesn’t come from the headlines. It comes from the whispers—executives who drink too much after a board meeting, analysts who think they’re clever by sharing “off-the-record” thoughts, or CFOs who forget they left a voicemail on a burner phone. I’ve learned to listen not just with my ears, but with my instincts.

My network is layered. At the top, there are a few high-value contacts—CEOs, directors, or those close to them. They don’t know me personally, but they’ve heard of my name. I cultivate trust by never overstepping, always keeping their identities protected. They think I’m just a consultant or a private investor. I let them believe that.

Then there are the middlemen: lawyers, brokers, even journalists who think they’re gatekeepers but are just conduits. They’re useful because they move between the legal and the gray. I get access to what’s coming down the pipeline before it hits the wires.

And then the underground—those who thrive in the shadows. They’re the ones who trade in silence, who know the value of discretion. They don’t care about the law; they care about the move. I’ve learned to speak their language.
